## FURTHER MATHEMATICS

9231/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 366, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025

2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 866, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 729, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents the sequence of two transformations in the \(x\text{-} y\) plane given by a stretch parallel to the \(x\text{-axis}\), scale factor 14, followed by a rotation anticlockwise about the origin through angle \(\frac{1}{3}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 144, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 108, 410, 140]]<|/det|>
Show that \(2\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} 14 & -\sqrt{3} \\ 14\sqrt{3} & 1 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 116, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 186, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 457, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation in the \(x\text{-}y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{M}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 613, 710, 633]]<|/det|>
The unit square \(S\) in the \(x\text{-}y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto the rectangle \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 644, 144, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 499, 663]]<|/det|>
Find the matrix which transforms \(P\) onto \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 644, 918, 663]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that \(2025^{n} + 47^{n} - 2\) is divisible by 46 for all positive integers \(n\). [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[967, 78, 992, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 618, 92]]<|/det|>
The quartic equation \(x^{4} + 7x^{2} + 3x + 22 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma , \delta .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 438, 125]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^2 + \beta^2 + \gamma^2 + \delta^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 917, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 560, 186, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 560, 438, 579]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^4 + \beta^4 + \gamma^4 + \delta^4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 562, 917, 583]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 144, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 71, 730, 89]]<|/det|>
Use standard results from the list of formulae (MF19) to find the value of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 92, 688, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{10}\bigl (\bigl (\alpha^{2} + r\bigr)^{2} + \bigl (\beta^{2} + r\bigr)^{2} + \bigl (\gamma^{2} + r\bigr)^{2} + \bigl (\delta^{2} + r\bigr)^{2}\bigr).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 101, 918, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 789, 92]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\nu_{r} = x^{\nu_{r + 1}} - x^{\nu_{r}}\), find the set of values of \(x\) for which the infinite series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 106, 566, 125]]<|/det|>
\[\nu_{1} + \nu_{2} + \nu_{3} + \ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 616, 155]]<|/det|>
is convergent and give the sum to infinity when this exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 426, 139, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 426, 504, 444]]<|/det|>
The line \(l\) is parallel to the vector \(3\mathbf{i} + 5\mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 453, 476]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(l\) and \(\varPi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 458, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 682, 88]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of any intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 71, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 504, 144, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 496, 504, 528]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \left|\frac{x^{2} + a}{x + a}\right|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 720, 102]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(a\) for which \(\left|\frac{x^2 + a}{x + a}\right| = a\) has two real solutions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 648, 95]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r^2 = \mathrm{e}^{\sin \theta} \cos \theta\), for \(-\frac{1}{2}\pi \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 917, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the polar coordinates of the point on \(C\) that is furthest from the pole, giving your answers correct to 3 decimal places. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 526, 186, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 524, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
Find the polar coordinates of the point on \(C\) that is furthest from the half-line \(\theta = \frac{1}{2}\pi\), giving your answers correct to 3 decimal places. [5]
